com.netflix.fenzo.queues

Interface TaskQueue

  • All Superinterfaces:
    TaskIterator
    All Known Subinterfaces:
    InternalTaskQueue
    All Known Implementing Classes:
    TieredQueue

    public interface TaskQueue
extends TaskIterator
    This interface defines a task queue that contains all tasks that are either pending resource allocation or assigned resources while continuing to run. When using task queues, tasks are input into Fenzo once. The tasks are then maintained in the queue until the task is explicitly removed due to no longer requiring resource assignment, or if the task completed for any reason.

    Methods in this interface are expected to be called concurrently. For example, tasks may be added to or removed from the queue while a scheduling iteration using this queue is in progress. Implementations must handle this.

    • Nested Class Summary

      Nested Classes 
      Modifier and Type Interface and Description
      static class  TaskQueue.TaskState
      Tasks in a queue are said to be in one of two states.

      • Methods inherited from interface com.netflix.fenzo.TaskIterator

        next

    • Method Detail

      • queueTask

        void queueTask(QueuableTask task)
        Add a task to the queue. Duplicates are not allowed, as in, a task request that has the same Id as another existing element will be rejected. The added task will be assigned resources by a scheduler. To add a task into Fenzo that is already running from before, use TaskSchedulingService.initializeRunningTask(QueuableTask, String).

        This operation is designed to be performed asynchronously, when it is safe to modify the queue. The queue implementations generally do not modify the queue while a scheduling iteration is in progress.

        Parameters:
        task - A task to add to the queue.

      • remove

        void remove(java.lang.String taskId,
            QAttributes qAttributes)
        Remove a task from queue with the given taskId and qAttributes. The task is removed from the queue, whether it is marked as queued for assignments or already marked as running. This must be called for all tasks that either no longer need resource assignments or if previously running tasks complete for any reason.

        This operation is designed to be performed asynchronously, when it is safe to modify the queue. The queue implementations generally do not modify the queue while a scheduling iteration is in progress.

        Parameters:
        taskId - The id of the task to remove.
        qAttributes - The queue attributes of the task to remove.
